annotation.TEXT: Sonar Wave is basically like a watered down version of Noise Crush (or even the Sonic Reflector from the DOS games). Its main gimmick is that it bounces off walls, but it's also locked on a horizontal path where you fire it. While it's relatively fast and has a decent ammo count, it doesn't seem to be any stronger than most of the other weapons in this game.

No, I don't know why Rockbot suddenly fired a charged shot either (he seems to do so at the start of levels on occasion). On the other hand, I'm really digging the mellow music here. Probably the best track in the game so far (even if it does deviate from the chiptune style that most of the other tracks used).

Just to note, there's an intentional death coming up, mainly involving the "Frog Coil" and a certain aspect of the stage itself. It's not exactly what you'd call a "well advertised" instant-death trap.

Seahorse Bot has a similar problem to Ape Bot, in that he can sometimes stay up high where you can't reach him (even with the underwater jump physics). Either way, his attacks aren't nearly as annoying as Ape's earthquake move, and he can be taken out easily with the Magic Star.

The dolphin mini-boss is probably the only thing this weapon is good for, and even then, it's the one large enemy in the game that you can completely bypass. I don't think the phrase "waste of time" is enough for this anymore.

This stage's gimmick (being one of the few in the entire game) focuses on platforms that you can fall through if you're not careful. At first glance, there's no real hint to tell which parts are fake, aside from the caterpillar enemies stopping short of where there's a gap. As it turns out however, the lighter parts of the platforms clue in on this (even though they're rather difficult to make out, along with making no sense to begin with).

The "Timed Bomb" is, bar none, the worst weapon I've ever come across in any Mega Man styled game (and perhaps one of the worst in any game, for that matter). Using it places a bomb directly where you're standing. You can't move or manually detonate the bomb at all, nor can you place more than one. You just have to let it sit there for several seconds until it blows up, effectively making it a gigantic waste of time. The worst part is that the bomb itself can be canceled out by numerous things (most notably, shielded enemies can actually knock it away).

No, you didn't just imagine that. The mini-boss in this stage is completely optional. I have no idea why, but it at least saves some time (and even if it wasn't optional, the dolphin is still incredibly easy to beat).

Spiked Chain does all kinds of things wrong. While it may be fast, its limited range and extremely low damage output quickly puts a hamper on any possible usefulness it could have had. Even though it has 28 uses, you'll more than likely plow through a quarter of them just to take down one or two enemies alone. Aside from weakness affiliations, this thing isn't leaving the bench.

Yes, touching the ceiling in this stage outright kills you. In a way, I'll admit that those portions do look a bit jagged, but they're nowhere close to the actual spikes (nor is this element properly introduced or even hinted at, making it a rather cheap death if you accidentally bump into it).

Since I have a bit of time left, and since I'm never going to use this thing for the rest of the playthrough, I may as well showcase just how awful this weapon is for a few minutes (I also show off the Spiked Chain a bit as well, but only because I got fed up with waiting for the bomb to work).

Aside from sounding like a rejected weapon from that Mega Pony game, Petals Rainbow functions almost like a terrible version of the Screw Crusher. The high speed at which it fires out coupled with its extremely wide arc make it highly unreliable in most situations. Unless an enemy is directly diagonal to you (that you can't hit with Desert Storm for some reason), this thing is nearly useless outside of weakness affiliations.

Yes, shielded enemies can actually cancel this thing out even as it starts to explode. At this point, I honestly feel like I need to give a formal apology to all the other weapons I deemed horrible before, both from official and fan-games. The Sakugarne and Police Shield were terrible, but at least they actually had the potential to hurt things they came in contact with.
